title: Contribute to this website
text:
This site is a Quarto website.
To learn more about working with Quarto websites see here
To link to another page, use markdown syntax. For example [this link](practical/workstations.qmd) points to the page about the workstations: this link.
To contribute, you have a few options:

For small changes, click the “Edit this page” link on the right of the page you want to change. It will redirect you to a markdown editor on GitHub.
You can also clone the repo vkola-lab-docs, edit the relevant markdown files and commit to the main branch. The website will be automatically built and deployed using GitHub Actions.


Creating a new page
Create a new .qmd file and make sure to include the YAML front matter. For example, this page starts with
---
title: "Contribute to this website"
author: "Matteo Bellitti"
date: last-modified
published-title: "Last Updated"
---
Make sure to only change the title and author fields. Then write the rest of the document in markdown. See markdown basics on Quarto’s website for a quick introduction.
The title field is used to generate the sidebar. Sub-directories will create sections and will be automatically titled based on the directory name (including adding capitalization and substituting spaces for dashes and underscores).


Quarto and VS Code
There is a VSCode extension that makes editing Quarto documents easier. See also the Quarto documentation about VSCode integration

title: Welcome
text:
Welcome
This is the knowledge base for the Kolachalama lab at BU.
If you have any suggestion, comment, or would like to see some particular topic covered, please open an issue on GitHub.

title: Using the Workstations
text:
There are three workstations available in the lab: ayan, echo, and manu. To access them, you can either use VSCode or SSH.

GPUs









Name
OS
RAM
GPU




ayan
Ubuntu 18.04.6 LTS
126 GB
4 x NVIDIA RTX 2080 Ti (11 GB)


echo
Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS
252 GB
4 x NVIDIA RTX 3090 (24 GB)


manu
Ubuntu 18.04.6 LTS
126 GB
4 x NVIDIA RTX 2080 Ti (11 GB)



You can check the status of the GPUs using nvidia-smi. For very long jobs please use SCC.


Remote access via SSH
You can get a remote shell on echo using
$ ssh user@echo.bumc.bu.edu
Where user is your BU username. You can also authenticate using an SSH key, so you won’t have to enter your password as often: if you don’t already have an SSH key pair, generate it
$ ssh-keygen
then copy your public key to the workstation
ssh-copy-id user@echo.bumc.bu.edu
You are now able to login without typing your password.


Using VSCode


Storage

title: Data Organization
text:
Data Organization
The datasets are currently being moved to the /18TB/Datasets directory on echo. The same directory is also accessible as /18TB_echo/Datasets from ayan and manu.
All datasets in the lab should follow the BIDS standard


Read/Write access
By default everyone has read access to the datasets, but to preven accidents only members of the dataset-editors are allowed do write (or delete) from the dataset directory. To check if you are in this group, look at the output of
$ groups
If you have sudo access and need to add a user to the group, use
$ sudo usermod -aG dataset-editors user
